I. INTRODUCTION
1. The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the developing member
countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to accelerate action on climate change,
thereby helping to implement ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priority 3 (OP3) on tackling climate
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability.1
The TA will build institutional capacity through technical support and policy advice to DMCs to (i)
develop long-term low-greenhouse gas (GHG) emission and resilient development strategies; (ii)
mobilize, track and report on climate finance; (iii) enhance management of climate and disaster
risks; and (iv) ensure national strategies and policies are aligned with the goals of the Paris
Agreement on climate change to limit the global temperature increase to 2 degrees C, and pursue
efforts to limit it to 1.5 degrees C.
2. The TA is aligned with Strategy 2030 and will support the implementation of the OP3
operational plan, specifically the following strategic operational priorities: increasing climate
change mitigation actions, and building climate and disaster resilience.2  The TA will also
contribute  to  other  operational  priorities,  specifically  1  (addressing  remaining  poverty  and
reducing inequalities), 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality), 5 (strengthening governance
and institutional capacity), and 7 (fostering regional cooperation and integration). The TA is
included in the 2019 and 2020 Management-approved results-based work plan of the Sustainable
Development and Climate Change Department. 3
II. ISSUES
3. The Asia and Pacific region is highly vulnerable to climate change, which pressures both
human and natural systems. The deterioration of Asia’s mountain “water towers”,4 prolonged heat
waves, coastal sea-level rise, and changes in rainfall patterns will disrupt ecosystem services;
this will in turn impact livelihoods, human health, and migration patterns, and possibly lead to
conflicts.5  The poor, women, children, and elderly will be disproportionately affected. The Asia
and Pacific region incurs an average of $200 million in daily losses due to disasters, and climate
change is increasingly exacerbating these losses.6 The high cost of addressing climate change
will increase if action on climate change is delayed.  While important steps have been taken to
mitigate and adapt to climate change, it is critical that DMCs increase their capacity to implement
action on climate change toward achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement and the Sustainable
Development Goals.
4. The Paris Agreement encourages countries to formulate and communicate long-term
(mid-century) strategies (LTSs) for low-GHG-emission development taking into account the
national development context, and the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities. To
collectively achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, countries need to establish long-term
targets informed by science, and identify feasible pathways for a just transition to a net-zero
emission,  resilient,  and  inclusive  economy.  LTSs  should  be  dynamic  instruments  that  are

embedded  in  the  national  planning  process,  establish  a  whole-of-economy  approach  to 
decarbonization  and  building  resilience,  while  seeking  to  maximize  economic  and  social 
development benefits.7 Once established, LTSs can guide short and medium-term decision-
making, including formulation of more ambitious Nationally Determined Contributions, and help 
DMCs manage tradeoffs between short-term benefits and long-term transition.8 LTSs will also 
provide greater long-term certainty to support expanded investment, including private sector 
investment, and investment in research, development and piloting of innovative solutions; and 
enable DMCs to better align financial flows with national climate-related actions and ambitions in 
order to prioritize low-carbon and resilient investments.9  
5. The Paris Agreement establishes the need for an LTS but does not specify the scope or
format, which can be determined by each country.10 Development of an LTS will require significant
national engagement and resources. It should be country-led, considering national development
priorities, strategies and plans, and reflecting the country’s resources, climate risk and GHG
emission profile. DMCs need to develop the necessary capacity to prepare for and plan their LTS
and manage its implementation and updating. The development process will require DMCs to
establish their long-term development vision and make decisions about preparing the LTS,
including how comprehensive it should be. They will need to establish sustainable processes for
stakeholder consultation, inter-ministerial coordination, governance, and decision making. The
LTS will be supported by sector and macroeconomic modelling, and DMCs need to identify and
build the capacity of national bodies or institutions that will undertake these activities.11 The
complexity of the LTS process is illustrated by the limited number of LTSs submitted to date to
the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change: 2 by ADB DMCs (Fiji and the
Marshall Islands), and 19 globally. ADB can support DMCs to strengthen their knowledge and
capacity for developing a robust and ambitious LTS, and establish sustainable processes for it to
be implemented and updated.
6. In  the  context  of  the  Paris  Agreement,  LTSs  refer  to  strategies  for  achieving
decarbonization by aligning long-term development pathways with the goal of achieving net-
zero emissions.  Identifying and accounting for climate risk is an equally important component
of long-term planning, and ADB supports a holistic approach to LTSs that identifies (i) long-
term pathways for achieving decarbonization; and (ii) approaches to adaptation that enhance
adaptive capacity, strengthen resilience, and reduce vulnerability in infrastructure, ecosystems,

3 
social and institutional structures, and the financial sector12. It is therefore important that DMCs 
build further capacity and understand concepts and available tools to identify climate and 
disaster risks, and incorporate actions related to climate change adaptation into their policies, 
strategies and long-term planning.  
7. The Paris Agreement’s Article 2.1c highlights the importance of aligning finance to
support  action  to  meet  climate-related  temperature  and  adaptation  goals,  reflecting  the
importance of ensuring that all finance (public, private, domestic and international) supports
and does not undermine the transition to low-carbon and resilient development. This will
require that governments and other stakeholders explore tools or mechanisms to manage the
transition, and build capacity to mobilize resources, track progress, and raise ambition.13 The
private sector has an important role in driving low-carbon and climate resilient growth in DMCs,
as a catalyst for greater and more frequent investments that lead to lower costs, more rapid
technology deployment, and more innovative financing approaches. Private sector finance
reached $326 billion on average annually during 2017–2018, accounting for 56% of total
climate finance. However, the private sector only accounted for $0.5 billion, or 2%, of the total
global adaptation finance during this period.14 Understanding the factors that limit private
sector adaptation finance and identifying approaches to increase it in the context of ADB’s
DMCs will support increased private sector engagement in adaptation. 15
8. The outcome of the TA for Enhancing Readiness of ADB Developing Member Countries
for  Scaled  Up  Climate Finance,16 supported  by the  Climate  Change  Fund,  was  increased
readiness of DMCs to access climate finance for low-carbon, climate-resilient infrastructure
projects. Approved in 2013 and closed in 2019, the TA supported ADB operations departments
to develop priority investment projects that could tap into international sources of finance. The
climate finance readiness component was highly relevant to the overall Climate Change Fund
objective  of facilitating greater climate change investment in DMCs. 17 This TA will build on this
initiative to further assist DMCs in improving their systems for accessing climate finance, as well
as promoting knowledge exchange and sharing of lessons from successful climate financing
applications, including experience with innovative mechanisms, reflecting the lessons from the
completed TA. Building DMCs’ climate finance capacity can also unlock new public and private
financing sources. Capacity building activities under this TA will build on lessons from past similar
activities, including ADB’s experience in the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience.18 For example,
the program in Tajikistan highlighted the benefits of a multi-stakeholder approach for capacity
building, involving participation beyond government and including civil society groups, which
improved climate change awareness, knowledge and skills among the participants.

9. The onset of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has further highlighted the
importance of long-term planning and a sustainable, low-carbon and climate-resilient recovery.
Countries must avoid letting concerns about the economic impact of the pandemic override the
urgency of taking climate action.19 Beyond the emergency COVID-19 response, DMCs must plan
for the medium-term recovery phase, including economic stimulus measures and possibly wider
accompanying reforms, and a longer-term transformation phase that could see wide-ranging
changes to systems, institutions, and policies.20 There is an urgent need for ADB to support
countries to direct stimulus spending toward interventions that can deliver strong economic and
social benefits to achieve recovery goals while also supporting actions related to climate change,
addressing vulnerabilities, and improving resilience.
10. ADB’s Strategy 2030 aims to achieve a prosperous, inclusive, resilient, and sustainable
Asia and the Pacific. ADB has set a target of ensuring that at least 75% of its committed operations
(by number, on a 3-year rolling average, including sovereign and non-sovereign operations) will
support climate change mitigation and adaptation by 2030. Climate finance from ADB’s own
resources is also targeted to reach $80 billion during 2019–2030. To implement OP3 and achieve
corporate climate targets, it is imperative that climate change and climate and disaster resilience
are mainstreamed in ADB operations. To do this, ADB needs to ensure that DMCs have the
capacity to identify and implement policies and strategies that support their climate change
mitigation and adaptation needs.
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
11. The TA is aligned with the following impact: capacity to integrate low-carbon and climate-
resilient solutions into national polices in Asia and the Pacific enhanced. The TA will have the
following outcome: implementation of climate actions in Asia and the Pacific increased.21
B. Outputs, Methods, and Activities
12. Output 1. Support to developing member countries in incorporating climate change
and resilience in long-term strategic planning and projects provided.  The output will support
DMCs to incorporate appropriate climate solutions into long-term strategic planning, including
sectoral strategies and investment projects, through the following activities: (i) support to develop
an action plan for the development of a comprehensive LTS in select DMCs,22 including: (a)
understanding  the  needs  and  benefits  of  an  LTS,  (b)  building  knowledge  of  development
approaches and analytical tools for LTS development, (c) mapping relevant stakeholders and
designing a stakeholder engagement process,23 (d) identifying capacity gaps in sectoral and
macroeconomic modelling capabilities, (e) assessing resource requirements for the development
process, and (f) establishing the governance processes; (ii) support DMCs to integrate low-carbon

development, and build climate and disaster resilience into COVID-19 recovery planning through 
training and direct technical support to identify COVID-19 recovery interventions that collectively 
achieve recovery objectives and promote low-carbon and climate resilient development;24 (iii) 
provide a roster of technical experts to support DMCs in integrating climate solutions in national 
policies  and  programs  and  investment  projects; 25 and  (iv)  develop  approach  papers  or 
frameworks that will enhance private sector investments in adaptation, align investments and 
programs with the Paris Agreement, and support DMCs to work towards a just transition. The 
roster of technical experts will support and advise DMCs in (i) identifying, developing and 
designing climate mitigation measures in investment projects;26 (ii) estimating associated costs of 
climate measures; (iii) assessing alignment of activities to the Paris Agreement; and (iv) advising 
on climate change strategies and policies, including LTSs.  
13. Output 2. Knowledge on climate change related concepts and tools improved. This
output will be delivered through the following activities: (i) conduct regional training programs to
build DMCs’ capacity in order to (a) enhance the understanding of the role of climate finance, how
to estimate and determine climate finance, and sources of climate finance (mitigation and
adaptation finance); (b) address climate change impacts and climate risk management; (c) align
investment projects and programs to the Paris Agreement; (d) increase knowledge of concepts
related to a just transition and LTSs, including their integration into national development planning;
and (e) support the design of low-carbon and climate-resilient interventions during the COVID-19
recovery period; and (ii) produce relevant knowledge products, including products addressing
regional climate finance, which will support transition by DMCs to low-carbon and climate-resilient
development. Through the regional training, DMCs will learn about and discuss existing climate
finance tracking frameworks and methodologies from various institutions; be exposed to the latest
information on climate science, data projections and best practices, including a range of potential
approaches for climate risk and vulnerability assessment, and methods for climate risk screening;
and  learn  about  and  apply  relevant  tools  to  help  align  strategies  and  investments  with
commitments under the Paris Agreement, as well as key factors involving successful development
and implementation of LTSs. Training activities will target various government ministries, including
finance, environment, economic development, and planning. Non-governmental organizations
and other stakeholders will also be invited to participate.
14. This will be ADB’s first LTS and just transition TA, and will significantly contribute to
advancing these important agendas in the region. Once established, LTSs can guide ADB’s
engagement in DMCs across all sectors, and through public and private lending, ensuring that
ADB’s lending and other activities are consistent with the countries’ development goals and
support a just transition. This includes through ADB’s country partnership strategy and project
design processes.  The TA will also support DMCs to consider their long-term climate goals as
part of planning their COVID-19 economic recovery, thereby supporting DMCs to ensure that
climate  action  is  not  delayed  or  de-prioritized  due  to  the  pandemic.  ADB  is  engaged  in
collaborative  mechanisms,  platforms  and  processes  supporting  action  on  climate  in  DMCs
(including LTSs and a just transition) and will coordinate with other development partners to
maximize the effectiveness of support to the DMCs. This includes initiatives such as the 2050
Pathways Platform—a multi-stakeholder initiative to support countries with LTS development—
and the joint multilateral development bank working group on Paris alignment. The TA is also the
first to conduct capacity building programs that cut across several key areas of finance and risk

C. Cost and Financing
15. The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the
Climate Change Fund.27  The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.
D. Implementation Arrangements
16. ADB will administer the TA. The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Division
of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will lead the implementation.
The Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department  will select, supervise, and
evaluate consultants; and organize regional training and provide staff to act as resource persons
for the training.  The TA will also support cross-sector and cross-thematic approaches by working
with operations departments and sector and thematic groups, ensuring that sector-, thematic-,
and DMC-specific issues are considered, and working synergistically. Government concurrence
will be sought prior to implementation of activities in a specific DMC.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Support to developing member countries in incorporating climate change and resilience in
long-term strategic planning and projects provided.
1.1  Identify DMCs to initiate work on action plans (Q1–Q4 2021)
1.2  Recruit relevant consultants to form an expert pool (Q1–Q2 2021)
1.3  Review documents and provide technical and expert advice on climate finance, climate strategy
and policy, climate mitigation, adaptation in the private sector, and alignment with the temperature
goals of the Paris Agreement (Q3 2021–Q3 2023)
1.4  Provide support for application of rapid assessment framework in DMCs (Q1 2021–Q2 2022)
1.5     Draft action plans for the development of LTSs (Q1 2021–Q1 2023)
1.6  Develop an approach paper to support private sector operations on enhancing adaptation finance
and resilience measures and a paper supporting DMCs for a just transition towards low-carbon and
climate resilient development (Q2 2021–Q4 2021)
1.7  Develop a framework, methodology and tools on integrating work on Paris alignment and climate
change programs (Q3 2021–Q4 2021)
2. Knowledge on climate change related concepts and tools improved.
2.1  Develop a training program module integrating concepts of climate finance, climate and disaster 
risks, and Paris alignment and low-carbon and climate-resilient COVID-19 recovery (Q1–Q2 2021) 
2.2  Organize and conduct regional training programs (Q3 2021–Q1 2023) 
2.3  Draft summaries and assess post-training surveys (Q3 2021–Q2 2023)

ABBREVIATIONS

LTS  – long-term strategy

GLOSSARY 
Long-term strategy  – Strategy  for  achieving  long-term  (often  focused  at  mid-
century)  low-emission  development,  considering  broader
goals  of  sustainability,  and  socioeconomic  and  climate
change adaptation and resilience.
Paris alignment  – Process  of  ensuring  that  an  institution’s  strategies  and
activities are consistent with the goals of the Paris Agreement
as described in Article 2.1a, b, and c, which sets objectives to
limit the global temperature increase to well below 2 degrees
C this century, and to pursue efforts to limit temperature
increase even further to 1.5 degrees C; increase adaptive
capacity; and make all finance flows consistent with low-
greenhouse gas emission and climate-resilient development
pathways.
